manufacturerProductDescription.media_text: Best-selling author Rick Riordan Presents the graphic novel adaptation of the New York Times best-selling fantasy adventure by Roshani Chokshi, inspired by the great Hindu epics she grew up on.

Roshani Chokshi is the author of the instant New York Times best-selling first book in the Pandava series, Aru Shah and the End of Time, and its four sequels. She also wrote the New York Times best-selling YA books The Star-Touched Queen, The Gilded Wolves, The Silvered Serpents, and The Bronzed Beasts. Joe Caramagna (adapter) is a writer and Harvey and Eisner-Award nominated comic book creator who has worked for both Disney Comics and Disney Games and Interactive Experiences. He has been involved with Duck Tales, Frozen, Big Hero6, and more. He is also a letterer for Marvel. He's from Elmwood Park, New Jersey, and loves his wife, three children, hockey, and donuts, though not always in that order. Aru Chouhan (artist) is a Punjabi illustrator from Vancouver BC, Canada. Growing up, she always knew she wanted to pursue a career in art and spent a lot of time learning about animation and fashion, while drawing inspiration from video games, movies (especially Bollywood), and nature. After completing her BA and earning a diploma in commercial animation, she worked as a mobile game artist for several years before going out on her own as a freelancer. Her unique edgy and energetic art has garnered attention on social media from major publications, celebrities, and influencers.
Read the entire series by New York Times best-selling author Roshani Chokshi

Aru Shah and the End of Time The Last Fallen Star Pahua and the Soul Stealer Tristan Strong Punches a Hole in the Sky The Cursed Carnival and Other Calamities Tristan Strong Punches a Hole in the Sky, The Graphic Novel Author Roshani Chokshi Graci Kim Lori M. Lee Kwame Mbalia Rick Riordan & Rick Riordan Presents Authors Kwame Mbalia, Robert Venditti, Olivia Stephens About Book one in a funny, and fast-paced New York Times Best-Selling fantasy adventure series loosely based on Hindu mythology, about a twelve-year-old girl who sets a cosmic showdown in motion when she lights an ancient lamp on a dare. Best-selling author Rick Riordan presents Graci Kim's thrilling debut about an adopted Korean-American girl who discovers her heritage and her magic on a perilous journey to save her witch-clan family. Best-selling author Rick Riordan presents Lori M. Lee's middle grade debut about a lonely Hmong girl who discovers she's a powerful shaman warrior in this fantasy inspired by Southeast Asian mythology. Discover Best-selling author Kwame Mbalia's epic fantasy, a middle grade American Gods set in a richly-imagined world populated with African American folk heroes and West African gods. Best-selling author Rick Riordan presents ten new stories--including one of his own--about beloved heroes that sprang from the imaginations of some of the best middle grade authors working today. The best-selling and awarding-winning novel about a Black boy who helps folk heroes and gods through storytelling is now a dynamic graphic novel!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 23, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars My 6th and 4th grader loved it
reviews.reviewText: Both my girls liked this book. Definitely a fun book for south Asian families and anyone else. But great to have a character they can identify with.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Beautiful illustrations bring this story to life!
reviews.reviewText: I loved the illustrations for this adaptation of Aru Shah and the End of Time! The colors were bright and eye-catching, and the pacing of the story was really good. After reading the book, I definitely enjoyed seeing illustrations of the characters and comparing those to the pictures I had in my head.I do hope that the rest of the series is adapted for graphic novels, too, because I would love to read those.As I have already read the sourcebook, I will include my review of that story below.:Aru lives with her mother in a museum of Indian artifacts. Since her mother travels quite often for her job, leaving Aru alone, Aru has developed a very active imagination. Exacerbated by the fact that she doesn't really fit in at school with the other students who are from very well-to-do families, she creates stories of trips she and her mother have taken and places they have lived that are much grander than the actual truth. Unfortunately, as typically happens when one stretches the truth a few too many times, some of her other classmates become suspicious and try to catch her in a lie. In an attempt to circumvent that potential disaster, Aru lights a lamp that her mother has warned her is cursed, and suddenly she is thrust into the middle of a quest to save the world - and she only has 8 days to do it.I loved this story. Though Aru's imagination does tend to get her into trouble, it also serves to get her out of trouble at times, too. The author did a great job of bringing the characters to life and, as they faced each challenge, they all grew, deepening their bonds with each other. The twists and turns that occurred, some of which I suspected and others that I did not, were all well-written. Even the ones that I did suspect were still somewhat of a surprise because I didn't fully guess what they would be.I think my favorite scenes are when Aru, Mini, and Boo meet with the Seasons and turn their own game back around on them, and when Mini and Aru finally get to the Hall of Weapons and discover that not everything is as it seems.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 18, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars great but cliffhanger
reviews.reviewText: I had listened to the first book as a audiobook and also found this. I was sad to see it speed everything up and lost some wonderful details. If you are not a person who likes reading books with cliffhangers this book may not be for you

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 26, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars This adaptation skipped important parts **SPOILER ALERT**
reviews.reviewText: I rated this 3 stars because the graphics were outstanding. But, the adaptation skipped some important parts. I felt this book was too rushed, and it didn’t give me the vibe I was looking for. Already on the 3rd page, a part that should’ve been a little more dragged out was already there! I was looking for a slower paced, enjoyable read. It went too fast in my opinion. Second, as I already said, they skipped important parts. At the end of the book you didn’t really understand what happened, and why (Sleeper wasn’t struck by the lightning bolt), if I hadn’t already read the novel, then I would’ve been confused as a reader of this graphic version of it. Another part they skipped was when they met Valmiki. They skipped many parts that would make this graphic adaption better than it is right now. If there is a second graphic novel of the second book in the Aru Shah series, I really hope they take my feedback into account. It would be much better.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on May 31, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars OBSESSED with the artwork!
reviews.reviewText: First I'd like to say screw my imagination cause this artwork is amazing!!! Kidding, Imagination is very good for the mind and soul but the work in this is so good! I love the Aru Shah series so, of course, I had to get my hands on this. Also the way I imagined the Sleeper way differently than the one shown here. Like I had pictured some random dude but the one picture in here is HOT! Forget my imagination I need to read more graphic novels!Thank You Disney Publishing for the copy!!!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2022
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Love this graphic novel version of the series!
reviews.reviewText: This graphic novel version of the first book of the Pandava Series gives readers a dynamic new glimpse into Aru Shah’s world! I think this is a great way to introduce a new set of readers to the Roshani Chokshi’s series based on Hindu tales–it incorporates all the important elements of the story, and the full color artwork is superb! I would still encourage kids to pick up the original books because this version doesn’t showcase Choksi’s gorgeous writing style and we lose out a bit on some of the humor from the books (especially when it comes to the character of Boo the pigeon). But this would be a great way to get kids interested in the story or for readers who already love the books to experience them in a new way!
